job_title: Senior Programme Officer in Washington, DC
pros: Super colleagues; great mission; good support structures
cons: Hard to be part of the action if you're not based in DC

pros: Indo Pacific and Asia Research
cons: Small team meaning heavy workload

pros: Great office culture and working environment.
cons: Some departments are not collaborating enough

job_title: Senior Level Role in Washington, DC
pros: Generally nice and knowledgeable colleagues willing to go above & beyond to achieve results and driven by the mission.
cons: Leadership is disconnect, nepotic, a highly dysfunctional organization at times very toxic culture. Delusions of grandeur about what the organization is. While the organization affords itself a very expensive and overblown executive & leadership team, the programs and offices need to justify hiring support staff or seek external funding to do so. Very few staff development opportunities, lots of lip service, and navel-gazing.

pros: Great opportunity for learning and growing in your field.
cons: Flexibility in operating blurs lines of responsibility excessively.

pros: Enthusiasm of the entire organizations
cons: Lacking a structured approach for day to day operations

review_title: Great Company, Does not Pay well
pros:
-Fulfilling work
-Great community and connections
cons: -Does not care for employee pay and suffers for it

pros:
- opportunity to meet high-level people
- growth opportunity (slow)
- ability to travel to interesting program locations
-good technical (IT) support
-good communication tools *mail, digests, news, updates available for everybody, etc*
cons:
- low pay for local staff
-almost no social benefits and expatriation allowances
-no cultural cohesion across offices
-micromanagement
-all depends on your luck with your colleagues, otherwise no one is responsible for discriminatory and bad organizational practices.

pros: benefits, intellectually stimulating context, smart coworkers
cons: Junior staff exploited and abused by entitled & well-payed senior staff, little to no accountability, HR unresponsive, everyone here is mostly miserable. Not a good place for POC.

pros: Great environment to meet people and build networks.
cons: Very little opportunities for career development for junior staff.

pros: A lot of flexibility and great benefits!
cons: lower pay for some positions.

job_title: Human Resources Director in Washington, DC
pros: mission; people; international travel; impactful work; autonomy
cons: challenging career progression and professional development

pros: Travel opportunity, good benefits after many years of working there, vacation time, you might have a good boss, international atmosphere can be fun
cons: Burns out just about every junior staff they have with crazy low pay, lots of expected overtime for events, poor management, and horribly dysfunctional HR department. They also don’t allow for any professional development, and often push out employees who have dedicated years of hard work just because they don’t want to pay them. I know this sounds just like a disgruntled employee review but I promise this is all fact, and unfortunately the norm for the think tank space in DC. Places like GMF have so much potential and advocate for so many good causes but can’t seem to get out of their own way when it comes to treating anyone below a director level with respect.

review_title: Good for first job in DC
pros:
Large pool of junior staff
Travel opportunities for junior staff
Interesting programs, fellows, contacts
cons:
Little to no room for growth
Bureaucracy
Incompetent leadership is allowed to continue unsupervised until enough staff complain

pros: Dynamic work environment; Chances to meet professionals and be part of groundbreaking research; Small office
cons: Focus on event planning; Focus on China

review_title: Great opportunity for growth, learning, travel and writing
pros: GMF is a leading institution for U.S. foreign policy with a historically European slant. It's a generally positive work environment, with lots of opportunity for young foreign policy analysts to attend discussions, help organize events and to travel to international conferences. There is a fairly comfortable work-life balance and the compensation is mostly on par or slightly better than similar NGOs or think-tanks. Most staff are very positive and friendly and the rather young staff demographic makes it a fun place to work.
cons: There has been quite a bit of turnover at GMF in recent years and a recent change in leadership, though the new President is a very respected Europeanist and was beloved as a former leader. The small size of the place also means some unequal and unpredictable changes in roles and responsibilities and some younger staff may feel 'stuck' in their position. Others may find the opportunity to move up, but it's entirely uncertain. Teams tend to inherit their work culture from their managers, so there are some large gaps in the temperament, pace and mood of different programs.  That can be either an advantage or disadvantage depending on which team you are on.  Recent turnover and staff changes have also caused GMFs general reputation to slide a bit among its peers.

pros: The company mission is clear and there is an appropriately positive work environment.
cons: While online, there's not much collaboration between divisions.

pros: The work was interesting at times
cons: Most fellows were approachable, but not great at communicating

review_title: Great place to work, but not forever
pros: Flexibility, international, informal, entrepreneurial, opportunities for continuous learning
cons: Very flat management that translates in very little guidance and supervision. Hard to grow inside the organization (maximum 4-5 years.) Very convening oriented for a think tank.

pros: Driven, intelligent, and focused executive team and Director-level staff. They really care about the people they employ and want to make a difference in this world. Lots of travel and long hours on the road, but an incredibly generous 35 hour work week during off peak times and absolutely unmatched benefits and vacation package (22 vacation days per year, nearly unlimited sick time).
cons: Like all transatlantic think tanks, GMF struggled to find it's place in a 21st century world. With the resurgence of Russia and the rise of populism, GMF has now solidified once again its place in the world of policy and thought leadership.

pros: This is a good place to work mainly because the benefits and work life balance can't be beat. Overall the staff is friendly with one another and there are social activities almost every week. Beautiful building in DuPont Circle. Opportunities for travel.
cons: GMF has experienced some growing pains in the last two years. The newly instated Executive Team gets less done and tends to push their own agendas above what is best for GMF. Your experience here will differ greatly depending on which team you're on. Some Directors are great to work with and others are definitely not. Some of the old guard is unqualified and overpaid and were promoted in to their positions years ago without getting additional training. There are also wonderful and highly skilled individuals.

pros: If you get the chance to work on issues in a way that actually has an impact, the work at GMF can be incredibly fulfilling. The people at GMF are amazing and are the main reason for its incredible success.
cons: Severely lacking HR department. Total confusion and mis-messaging on compensation. Junior staff works incredibly hard for unacceptably low pay.

pros:
- a great team with different interesting project areas
- relaxed atmosphere in the office, independent work encouraged
- open atmosphere between colleagues, who support each other across teams
- international office, English main language
- flexible structures and policies allow for experimentation and innovation
cons:
- organisational structures are often unclear and responsibilities not clearly allocated, which makes coordination (especially across different offices) difficult
- no long-term opportunities for junior staffers and no transparency about such a policy, which leads to disappointment and a feeling of not being appreciated
- some structures are rather rigid

review_title: No need to do this fulltime - highly dependent on supervisor
pros: If you get some great tasks to do, its true fun and great experience - lots of insightful events. They do hire former interns regularly! Beware it's only partly a thinktank - more producing op-eds than reports; and the emphasis is on connecting to/across the atlantinc high-level stakeholders through (closed) events.
cons: The whole experience depends highly on your supervisor - if you don't get cool tasks, it's literally sitting around wasting your time. Thus I was perfectly fine with just pursuing it part-time, no one ever complained.

review_title: It was a challenging experience yet yielded significant professional growth.
pros:
-Great opportunites for networking and learning from others.
-Many experienced and professional co-workers.
-Interesting projects.
-Access to a wide range of events and interesting high-level guests.
cons:
-Limited opportunities for career progression. However, this may also be tied to the economic crisis.
-Management structure can be a bit bureaucratic and static.

review_title: A lot to learn if you know how to take advantage of it
pros: There was always something going on, whether it was a conference, a roundtable discussion or a visit from a foreign delegation. This offered everyone, from interns to top-level executives, the chance to mingle and attend an event.
cons: Sometimes it feels like there is no real point to what is being done at GMF.

pros: entrepreneurial environment, solid mission, well intentioned, several stellar well respected programs
cons: operations and finances are very poorly managed, lacks clear focus, continuous funding challenges, poor attempts at fundraising with consistency, serious lack of transparency and weak internal communications

pros: In GMF it's all about who you work for, whether you'll have a ton of free time or be busy regularly with important work to do. The good part is most people seem to have this experience!
cons: It would be nice if interns were paid, or if there was a travel stipend.

pros: People are incredibly friendly and helpful.  The work is interesting at times.
cons: Upper management is scattered and does not have clear vision to pass on to lower level employees.

pros: Great work environment, excellent leadership from the President, fellows do interesting work
cons: Internship is unpaid, but interns are mostly college graduates, work 40 hours a week and strongly support all day to day activities. This is typical of DC but still frustrating.

pros: great people, open non-competitive atmosphere, good benefits and working hours, opportunities to travel to lots of new and interesting places
cons: tough to get ahead and receive promotions

pros: Intellectually stimulating work, great coworkers
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for moving up professionally

pros: Great work experience, with a great time. Work was interesting and always challenging.
cons: The amount of work fluctuates every week

pros: Good work environment and good people
cons: Does not pay, and there are days when you have nothing to do

review_title: Good place to start ones career
pros: Good collegiality among entry and mid-level staff
